reviewText: This game is by far one of the most fantastically crafted and detailed horror games I have ever played. The fact that this game was created by a single person shocks me, for it is so detailed and so perfectly displays all of the horror movie tropes we have come to know and love through the years. To thoroughly enjoy this game you must have an imagination to craft a story for these characters, who are basically blank canvases meant to have a personality crafted for them by the player. There also is a briliantly crafted yet oddloy convoluted story that at this point has not been fully revealed due to the fact that only two episodes have been released thus far, yet if you are a person who is fit and able to search out a hidden backstory within a game will be pleasantly suprised. The gameplay is simple due to the fact that it completely revolves around a pick up and throw mechanic I have not seen in any other two dimensional pixelated indie games, yet it feels like this mechanic should have been used from the start in the horror game genre. The second episode feels like an entirely different game, due to the fact that the creator chose to go with a Texas Chainsaw Massacre approach instead of his usual Friday The 13th feel, but still proves to be as incredibly, if not even more, replayable. What the creator has accomplished thus far is incredible, being that he is a single developer who is somehow able to create a game that I, and many others would consider better than most triple a titles released this year. Few other games had me constantly checking the developers twitter for updates on the games progress, and I dont even have an account on that site. This game is so criminaly underplayed that it makes me sick. If you are a fan of anything horror related, it is a neccesity that you buy this game, and if the creator of this game sees this post, please make me a tester, for never before have I wanted to be involved in a games developement more than I would to have the privalige to help you develope this amazing game.

reviewText:
This game is... Something.

Basically, the premise is that you play through rip offs of classic horror movies. LVC 3 apes Friday the 13th, LVC4 apes Texas Chainsaw Massacre, LVC 5 apes Halloween, and I'm not sure what 6 apes yet.

Each level is an open ended adventure puzzle game, essentially, with each one having distinct objectives. For instance, in 3 you are simply trying to ward off the killers without all four of your teenagers (that you control one at a time) dying. In 4, you are searching a truly demented mansion and slaughterhouse for gas so the band you play as can make their next gig. In 5, you try to avoid a Michael Meyers esque killer while summoning monsters that can bring him down.

There's a lot to like with this game. For one, each level is very distinct from the others. The first is probably the most open ended and trial and error one, because it's a very small, confined setting. It's the one that is quite tough to figure out, but once you do, it's pretty rewarding. Plus, there are lots of things you can do in the environment, so it's fun to experiment. While 3 is relatively tame despite the gore, 4 and 5 ramp up the creep factor. Yes, believe it or not, this game actually manages to be pretty disturbing and creepy thanks to its sound design and creative use of visuals. Both 4 and 5 have an extremely macabre and dark feeling to them that 3 simply does not, and it's pretty welcome.

I will say that certain elements stand out as flawed. For one, the layout of the buildings in 4 is entirely RNG, and it can glitch so that, without giving too much away, you can't continue. This is really annoying, as I've died more than once in that level simply because of the rng. Additionally, 5 is one I simply needed a guide for. Originally, I felt bad, but after actually seeing the solution, I don't, because it's very obtuse. Fun and macabre, but very, very obtuse.

Still, this is worth checking out for people who love old horror films and are in the mood for something different. It's definitely not a game that holds your hand, and you may need a guide every now and then, but the wonderful mixture of humor and truly disturbing content as well as the open ended gameplay make this stand out as a real gem. I'm looking forward to the sequel, and hope that the creator refines it even more to make an even better game than this one.

reviewText: I heavily recommend this game. Lakeview Cabin is a sidescrolling game with pretty simple graphics, and a rather interesting concept. While it may look simple, the gameplay is actually pretty complex and requires planning, tactics, and timing. This is technically an episodic series, and as of this writing, there is only one episode out (Other than the secret one). The first episide's plot is simple: you're playing as a bunch of teenagers in a summer camp on an island, which gets invaded by various killers, and your goal is to kill them, or be killed yourself. The main draw of this game is that there's no single path to take as you dispatch the killers. There's a TON of options and variety - but at the same time, you'll have to do a TON of experimenting and planning to see what does and does not work. It's... pretty trial and error, honestly. While I don't like that brand of gameplay, it's pretty rewarding once you succeed. However, if your plan fails even slightly, most of the time you're better off just starting from scratch. Alternatively, you can do whatever the hell you want - the game doesn't punish you until the killers come. So, for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, you can play out your very own 80's horror movie scenario! It's fun to kick around in and definitely worth the modest price tag, but be sure to play in private; the true horror experience comes from trying to explain to a loved one, or housemate, that having an ingame orgy is crucial to your survival.

reviewText:
Lakeview Cabin Collection is a parody of various horror movies of 70's and 80's. Here, you get a band of typical horror protagonists at your hands, and your goal is to make them survive against various maniacs and hazards.

The biggest hazard will actually be you. Have you always wondered why all these slasher movie heroes are so dumb? Why do they always split up? Why do they never watch where they go? Why don't they just bash the maniac with that handy candlestick right next to them? Why don't they stuff him into the grinder so he never rises up again?

Well, you're going to make all the stupid decisions a slasher movie protagonist ever made, and lead your characters to their bloody but hilarious demise. After a few bad endings, you will manage to get at least some of the heroes to survive the attack and put the monsters to rest...

Only to fail spectaculary in the next chapter! I won't spoil it for you, but the gameplay changes drastically, even though all the mechanics are the same. And then the third chapter is going to surprise you even more, going from slashers to mystery thriller territory.

The graphics may look simplistic, but there are a lot of nice touches like the sun flickering in the lake or an oscillating weather vane. Overall cartoony art style plays greatly for the whole parody thing, sometimes you just can't help but laugh (maybe with some hysteria notes) watching a chibi-proportioned maniac with an axe closing in on your poor hero. Even more hilarious when overly dramatical high-pitched cello music starts playing and scare chords empathize his blows.

All in all, Lakeview Cabin Collection is a great game, which manages not only to capture the feel of the old horrors, but does it in just right proportions and, most of all, has a solid, interesting and challenging gameplay.

As of today, this game has roughly 12k owners according to Steamspy. It definitely deserves more attention!

Lakeview Cabin is best known for the flash game that has been circulating the internet for a while, portraying a peaceful scenario, where you seemingly have the freedom to do whatever you want without a guideline up until the point where everything turns gruesome as you are hunted down by a monster.
The current episode released (Lakeview Cabin III) goes by that same formula, except with 4 characters that can be played to make survival possible (Or you let everyone hide and only one person does all the work).
This game gives you a setting and basicly allows you to re-enact scenarios reminiscent of 80's slasher fics, where you decide on how to dispatch/survive your pursuers and wether or not your friends live or die (by the murderer's hands or even your own) and giving you a sense of freedom to set up your own horror movie.

Note: This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer. This is a work in progress review, I will update this review when the other episodes are released.

Lakeview Cabin 3- Review

Lakeview Cabin Collection took me by surprise once it was released. I played the original flash game and thought the idea was very interesting and had a lot of potential and then I saw that the original developer made a new game, on a bigger scale.

To begin with the game doesn't hold your hand when you start playing, you have to figure out everything by yourself otherwise you won't get anywhere.

The gameplay is simple. You take control of four campers who get attacked by serial killers and it's up to you to survive. You can set up traps or you can try and take down the killers with brute force, but it's best to take the cautious approach otherwise you won't survive.

The audio is really well done and is one of the games best features. The sound effects are awesome and sound a lot like the effects in those very cheesy slasher movies that the game is based of.

The game is overall really well made apart from a few minor bugs like characters not picking up the thing you want them to pick up.

Lakeview Cabin 3 is a really great episode and a good start to what seems to be a very promising game. I give Lakeview Cabin 3 a 8.5/10

Lakeview Cabin 4- Review

Lakeview Cabin is the second episode in the Collection.  The first episode took us to a camp site like Friday the 13th, but this time we go to a mansion and try not to get killed by a crazy cannibal family.

Lakeview Cabin 4 changes a lot of gameplay aspects from the first episode. This time you need to find 4 gas canisters to fuel up your car and escape a mansion full of crazy cannibals, but to get them you need to kill a lot of people.  Killing increases your crazy meter which makes the screen go crazy and makes more jump scares appear. Enemies are easier to kill but there's more of them and now there's stealth to avoid an even bigger threat which you can't kill so you will have to be more careful.

This episode is very interesting and it feels fresh which I like a lot. Now for the good. The audio is still really good. The gameplay is very fun and challenging which is a lot of fun. Funny like always and the graphics are awesome.

But there are a few problems. This episode was really buggy. An enemy hit me through a door which was closed, and of course the same problem where my character wouldn't pick up what I wanted to pick up. The random aspect of the episode is a great way to add replay value, but for people who have a hard time with the game might have more trouble since they can't learn from they're mistakes.

Overall it's still a very fun game and I can't wait to play Episode 3 or Lakeview Cabin 5 whatever you want to call it. It's worth the full price without a doubt. I give Lakeview Cabin 4 a 7.5/10

Lakeview Cabin 5 - Review

Taking  a detour from the previous play style of the other episodes the third episode of Lakeview Cabin takes more of a puzzle game approach. Lakeview Cabin 5 makes you play as four teenagers again in a place that is taken straight out of Halloween the movie.

The goal in this episode is quite different. You can't die this time, but you have one goal to figure out how to kill a murderer who is immortal.

As stated before this takes a more slow paced approach than the other two episodes. This time it's more about puzzle solving than anything. I liked the puzzle solving in this episode and some of the puzzles are incredibly crazy not to mention some of the solutions are absurd, but it's incredibly fun non the less.

When I began this episode, I loved the retro feel. It felt like Halloween the movie with Nightmare on Elm Street characters. This for me the best looking Lakeview Cabin Episode by far.

Now for the bad and there is a lot this time. The episode is the buggiest episode by far. I had to relaunch the episode several times after finishing one of the puzzles due to the audio cutting out after I finish it. Not to mention the very weird movement of the killer. Sometimes he doesn't attack you at all and just jitters and place.

In the end I loved Lakeview Cabin Episode 3, because of the puzzle solving aspect. In the end if the bugs weren't there I would say it's the best episode right now.

If you don't own Lakeview Cabin Collection right now, you just simply need to get it. It's one of the most fun you can have with a horror title.

Lakeview Cabin 5 gets a 8/10

10/10 would zip down a line into a working wood chipper again.

Ahhh, Lakeview Cabin. I was the lucky winner of this game on one of the steam groups I belong to, and I was pleasantly surprised with the creepy pixelated experience.

Really, the game page says it all:

”Relive the horror movies of the 70's and 80's by answering the question: What would you do if you found yourself in a slasher film?”

And that’s exactly what the game is: A perfect, pixelated representation of your typical horror movie of the 80’s. There you have the girls with their lovely hair, and the boys with their handsome beards, and the creepy lake, and the cabins, and the creepy nude stalker…


Wait, what? o.O

The game is a horror/comedy/parody/adventure type of game. Your goal? To prepare yourself to survive the creepy, murdering monster as long as possible. Or, you know, you could just hide forever.

There are several characters for you to deal with, and switching between them is super easy.
You get to explore the cabins, find items to aid you with surviving, places to hide, and weapons to use against the horrors of the night. Whenever you get hurt, you actually… get hurt. As in, you miss a leg and you’ll be hopping down that pixelated grass on one leg while bleeding off. the game spares no expenses in the pixelated gore.

You can also kill yourself, kill others, and promptly die when you’re the only one left to face the evil from the lake. There’s more than one way to kill or be killed, and exploring them all is as fun as playing the game as you should be. :)
And you know what’s more satisfactory than surviving? Not giving the monster the chance to kill you all off, by doing it yourself first. :P

The game is mostly funny to play, but it also, despite being just pixels, manages to be sufficiently creepy as to unnerve you.  The replayability is fairly decent, as you can just replay it to see how many different ways you find to survive, whether you can kill the monster at all, and how long you can last.

If you’re into a bit of pixelated parody horror, give this one a try! Be warned, though: If you want to play this as it’s intended (as opposed to killing everyone yourself, actually laying traps out for the evil thing), be prepared to be a bit frustrated at the time constraints until you get the hang of what to do.

Looking forward to future episodes!

reviewText:
A Splendid Horror Homage

Lakeview Cabin makes me jump, but not in the cheap way so many other horror games seem to.  It does it In the proper way, using atmosphere, timing and many of the tricks from the well-thumbed slasher film rulebook. The game uses sound and score superbly in this regard, the sudden cries of the crows seem filled with portent, the creak of a rafter, a door opening somewhere off screen. It all helps build the tension beautifully.  The charm of the chunky sprites and backgrounds lend extra heft to the stabs of panic inducing action, too. The cute pixel characters offset nicely against the horrific situations.

For me, each episode of Lakeview gets better with every attempt. While the challenge of getting one character to the end of an episode without significant blood loss would probably not be enough to keep me playing, it is the detail in the design of each distinct episode and the individual stories that have me returning for more. All the episodes are challenging and amusing in their own macabre ways, each having more emphasis on certain of Lakeview's gameplay elements. If I had to pick a favourite it'd be the puzzle heavy Episode 5. The supernatural elements are clevery used and the suburban setting is perfect, right down to the kid brother's toy laser gun.

My only criticism is one that could possibly be chalked up to my own inferior grey matter. I simply cannot fathom what to do in episode 4. It's great fun to play but invariably I end up with every character reduced to a fine pixel paste within ten minutes and not the foggiest glimmer of a clue about how to progress on the next attempt. As far as I can tell the aim is simply to be suddenly butchered in the most amusing way possible.

As an homage to 70's and 80's horror and slasher films as well as classic adventure/puzzle games they don't come much better than this one.  Looking forward to Episode 6!

reviewText:
Usually, when you hear the phrase Horror Comedy, what is being described is a comedy with the dressings of horror.  Movies like Tucker and Dale vs Evil or Shaun of the Dead aren't so much scary as they are kind of gross or gory sometimes, but the comedy is solid and the movies themselves are excellent.

Lakeview Cabin is a unique example of the genre.  When someone says Lakeview Cabin is Horror Comedy, what they mean is that it epitomizes both separate genres equally.  Lakeview Cabin is tense and freaky and, in general, simply excellent at that Horror trick of making you do something while every part of your body tells you not to, especially considering its crude, pixelly style (or, perhaps, partially because of it).  Your heart will race as you try to execute that last, desperate plan to save your own skin as an immortal serial murderer bares down on you in the dark.  At the same time, the freedom it allows the player in its little sandbox levels, combined with the game's swift, incredibly violent consequences of poor decision making, almost immediately opens up a world of hugely bloody, absurd comedy.  In few other games can you run to pick up a shotgun and blast a monster in the face only to discover it is empty, and the only other nearby object is a small pug which has been wandering the island carefree for days now, and in no other games can you desperately pick up that pug and try to hurl it at your killer's face, only for it to soar into a nearby running woodchipper instead, spraying blood and bits of bone at a hapless friend standing nearby.

The game has a sick and hilarious sense of humor, and, at the same time, is thrilling, tense, and off-puttingly weird.  Is that pregnant redneck trapped in the attic the source of all these slimy, bloodthirsty creatures slithering and snuffling through the walls?  Is that a man-sized, deformed infant careening around the island with a knife?  What are they doing with all these chickens?  What is that thing in the lake, and what did it do to our dog?  What are those two naked twins doing in the bathroom with that dessicated corpse?  These are but a tiny fraction of the worrying questions you'll pose to yourself while playing Lakeview Cabin Collection.

If you're at all a fan of weird sandbox titles, 70s grindhouse horror flicks, horror in general, comedy, combinations of the two, solving puzzles, playing games, or being a cool person, you should strongly consider giving this a shot.

Is that pregnant redneck trapped in the attic the source of all these slimy, bloodthirsty creatures slithering and snuffling through the walls?  Is that a man-sized, deformed infant careening around the island with a knife?  What are they doing with all these chickens?  What is that thing in the lake, and what did it do to our dog?  What are those two naked twins doing in the bathroom with that dessicated corpse?  These are but a tiny fraction of the worrying questions you'll pose to yourself while playing Lakeview Cabin Collection.

If you're at all a fan of weird sandbox titles, 70s grindhouse horror flicks, horror in general, comedy, combinations of the two, solving puzzles, playing games, or being a cool person, you should strongly consider giving this a shot.

reviewText:
The Lakeview Cabin Collection is a surivival horror action puzzle game for STEAM.

Before I talk about what I disliked about it, let me talk about what I enjoyed. It covers several genres of horror that I grew up with, from the killers, to the scenes and settings. The nostalgila factor alone already makes this game pretty good.

I like the art, it's retro, while still having it's own style and being able to separate itself from all the games that use the entire concept of retro art it's whole selling point.

The game also manages to be able to tell a story in a very basic manner without needing to have any sort of text. And I respect that. They did it in a much better way then Scott could ever hope to do with Five Nights At Freddies.

Now for the bad. To begin with, the controls are kind of wonky, it's going to take you awhile to get used to the very minimalistic controls they use. The game uses 'context senestive' icons to let you know when you can perform an action, but it isn't always clear what it is or what it's used for.

The hit detection in this game is terrible. 9 out of 10 times, an enemy will hit me before I even get remotely close to it, but the game, for whatever reason, seems to think I need to be right on top of an enemy to attack it. There's hard and then there's poor programming and this game could use a better combat system. At least give players the same attack reach the enemies do, that's only fair.

reviewText:
My favorite game in recent memory. Seamlessly blends the beautifully-nostalgic properties of Maniac Mansion with the old NES Friday the 13th game, in a sandbox-style engine.

There's *much* more to it than that, of course; I'm merely paraphrasing. The music is absolutely fantastic (as are the sound effects), and even the hub world has an interesting mystery to discover. But seriously, I cannot stress enough just how amazing the atmosphere is in this game.

Needless to say, as a huge fan of old NES horror games, and old newgrounds-esque flash games alike, this game is right up my alley. I cannot wait for the new episodes! 10/10

TLDR: LVC3 is Beautiful, and funny but lacks replay value once everything is found, LVC4 lacks humor but is still scary and brutally hard, however the random genertating of everything in the level doesnt help to the games advantage and can leave players un able to beat the level, or practically so. LVC5, is a fresh new look still funny stillscary everything i loved about part one in a brand new setting with 3 endings. whats not to love.
PART 1:Okay so this game is legit one fun sandbox horror, its funny and scary at the same time ive found myself more scared of this game than five nights at ♥♥♥♥faces could have and. the only problem i have with this game is that i just finished all of the game thats here so far and... there isnt any more i really wanna keep playing but replay value is kind of killed when you play it over and over exploring just trying to find a way to kill th e♥♥♥♥ing monsters. sure there is tons to do, like have sex with someone get drunk get naked kill your firends bring them back to life and kill them again throw there bodys in the wood chipper, get high have sex while high attempt to kill the monsters... over... and over.... and over... untill you finally find out how to do it then when you win you feel that acomplishment however... by the time you actually win... its kinda hard to find mmore to play. yeah there is the lake of the dead however after you kill 85 zombies by hiding behind a tree with an ax it kinda gets slower. so i think that more pieces need to be reliesed so that the replay value can return. so while there is no more to do with not alot of replay value
PART 2: For Lake View Cabin 4, i was pleasently surprised when the game felt fully fledged and brand new, there are more weapns more things to find, and its gruesomly harder, and very unforgiving of mistakes, but i guess one of the major flaws for this chapter is that it lacks that funny charm that made the firt episode so much fun, it was funny and charming while bing scary and brutal at teh same time, while i love more content, its still a brand new game all together and its absolutly brutal. honestly. im not sure the random generation helps this game. becasuse, sometimes you dont get a good spawn and it makes the run nearly impossible. so its not perfect but its a hell of a ride and its great
PART 3: for the 5th installment of the game, i just love how different each chapter is from each other, its the same place, but the story is so vastly differnt and the way the game plays is so much crazyer, and its still one of the scaryest games ive encounteres mixing with random pop up dad with scary atmosphere and spooky minigames and, just to mix things up you can still have sex, while you cant have an orgy you can still do it, the point is its still funny and still charming whle maintaining a fresh new look yet still scary as ♥♥♥♥. honetly. this game has done alot to impress me. i love this game. 9.5/10
